April 26, 2003 Beijing, China - Amid rumors that the Beijing government isabout to invoke martial law (denied by officials so far), 4000 residents suspectedof SARS contamination were ordered to stay home in quarantine yesterday.Beijing authorities also sealed off the city's third major hospital as the number ofnew SARS cases jumped from 37 to 877 in only five days. Ditan Hospital innorthern Beijing was closed only a few days after the Beijing government hadfeatured the hospital as an example of their health care organization and abilityto control SARS. Earlier this week, Peking University's People's Hospital wasalso closed, along with Northern Jiaotong University where 400 students arequarantined.So far in China's capitol of 13 million people, more than 750 people are sickwith the coronavirus pneumonia and at least 42 patients have died. As of April25, the World Health Organization was reporting 2,601 cases in China and 115deaths (4% mortality rate). Hong Kong is treated as a "special administrativeregion," with 1,510 cases and 115 deaths (8% mortality rate).Many schools and offices have closed and shopping malls, restaurants, hotelsand general city life has come to an eerie silence for a city of 13 million people. Beijing Medical Workers Warned by Government Not ToLeave WorkHealth authorities estimate that one in eight of Beijing's SARS cases are medicalworkers and some doctors and nurses have reportedly left the city to escape thedeadly virus. So, the government has warned the medical community that theirmedical licenses will be permanently revoked if they don't keep working. Toronto, Canada Remains on W.H.O.'s Travel Advisory ListW.H.O. is still advising all optional travel to be delayed to Toronto where thereare 140 SARS cases and 15 deaths (10.7% mortality rate). Angry Torontogovernment officials demanded that W.H.O. rescind its warning, but W.H.O. has

refused. Meanwhile, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, Georgia, joinedthe argument by siding with Toronto government in a rare public disagreementwith W.H.O.W.H.O.'s Director of Communicable Diseases, David Heymann, argues thatCanada SARS patients are known to have transported the pneumonia virus tothe United States, Australia and the Philippines, and the only way to slow downthe SARS spread is to reduce person-to-person contamination.In other travel-related news, Great Britain travel insurance providers arewithdrawing coverage for some SARS-infected countries.SARS Cases as of April 26, 2003 Reported by CDC andW.H.O.
